repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: nvim_buf_set_text() and nvim_buf_set_lines() do not set the '[ and '] marks after changing text, so users cannot use '[ to jump to the start of the changed text.

Solution: Set b_op_start and b_op_end in both functions after changing lines, matching the behavior of regular edit operations.

Fix #32424

<!--
  Thank you for contributing to Neovim!
  If this is your first time, check out https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests-prs
  for our PR guidelines.
-->

comment_data.body: why is a new test needed? can we just check the marks in an existing test(s)?

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -482,6 +482,28 @@ describe('api/buf', function()
       eq({ 'xxx', 'yyy', 'zzz' }, api.nvim_buf_get_lines(0, 0, -1, true))
       eq({ '' }, api.nvim_buf_get_lines(buf, 0, -1, true))
     end)
+
+    it("sets '[ and '] marks", function()

comment_data.body: why doesn't changed_lines set the marks ? is there some other function that maybe does it for us ? it's surprising that (1) this didn't already work and (2) it requires so much code
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -673,6 +692,26 @@ void nvim_buf_set_text(uint64_t channel_id, Buffer buffer, Integer start_row, In
 
     changed_lines(buf, (linenr_T)start_row, 0, (linenr_T)end_row + 1, (linenr_T)extra, true);

comment_regular_data.body: any code re-use possible here? either old code can use these APIs, or vice-versa...
emm there has different mark calculation logic.. so i guess no.
Is this really desired? `nvim_buf_set_text` and `nvim_buf_set_lines` are not "regular edit operations". They are APIs, which should at a lower-level than regular edit operations.

> `nvim_buf_set_text` and `nvim_buf_set_lines` are not "regular edit operations". They are APIs, which should at a lower-level than regular edit operations.

That's a fair point. I see also that `setline()` doesnt set the `'[` marks. So maybe we should just document this a bit more clearly.

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32424#issuecomment-2654918051 links to issues that do look more legitimate though. Does this PR fix those ?

> https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32424#issuecomment-2654918051 links to issues that do look more legitimate though. Does this PR fix those ?

The issues in the links all have corresponding PRs and are unrelated to this. maybe turn this into a doc PR to document the behavior and then close the issue ..

> Is this really desired? `nvim_buf_set_text` and `nvim_buf_set_lines` are not "regular edit operations". They are APIs, which should at a lower-level than regular edit operations.

plugins use these functions to act as "normal edit" such as mini.surround uses `nvim_buf_set_text` to replace original text with added pair; vim-surround uses another way, visual select that area and paste the pair text from register so it correctly set marks, but those implementation details shouldn't affect whether marks are set or not from users perspective.

> plugins use these functions to act as "normal edit"

> but those implementation details shouldn't affect whether marks are set or not from users perspective.

Aren't those the plugins' implementation details? Why should Nvim handle those?

Example where this not desired:
```vim
call setline(1, ['foo', 'bar', 'foo', 'bar', 'foo'])

func OpFunc(type)
  for lnum in range(getpos("'[")[1], getpos("']")[1])
    if getline(lnum) ==# 'foo'
      call nvim_buf_set_lines(0, lnum - 1, lnum, v:true, ['FOO'])
    endif
  endfor
endfunc

set operatorfunc=OpFunc
normal! ggg@G
echomsg getpos("'[") getpos("']")
```

Before this PR it prints `[0, 1, 1, 0] [0, 5, 1, 0]`, but after this PR it prints `[0, 5, 1, 0] [0, 5, 3, 0]`.

`nvim_buf_set_lines` currently returns void. It could return a dict containing the modified region (see https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/31903 ). That allows plugins to easily set the `'[` `']` marks if they want.

title: fix(api): set '[ and '] marks in nvim_buf_set_text/lines
